title: Ropy Ronnie O’Sullivan squeezes past world number 105 in English Open first round
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan (Picture: Getty Images)

Ronnie O’Sullivan survived a serious scare in round one of the English Open as he came from behind to scrape past world number 105 Jamie O’Neill 4-3.

The Rocket fell 2-0 and 3-2 behind to the former tiler as he took on a range of questionable shots and handed the underdog chance after chance.

There were moments of brilliance from the five-time world champion – breaks of 102, 90 and 81 – but also signs of his temperament letting him down as he continually took on the wrong shot.

Ultimately it did not cost him and he is into Wednesday’s second round where he will take on either China’s Yuan Sijun or Brazi’s Igor Figueiredo, but he cannot repeat a performance so loose against an opponent of more quality and experience.

He's through! But it wasn't easy. @ronnieo147 fights back from 2-0 down to win 4-3. 👏 🎱 Watch the #EnglishOpen LIVE:

📺 – Eurosport 1

📱💻🖥 – Eurosport Player: https://t.co/0Fa7uXMVB9 pic.twitter.com/GcZNJ5eKYS — Eurosport UK (@Eurosport_UK) October 14, 2019

Advertisement

Advertisement

O’Sullivan started the game with reckless abandon, playing some outrageously aggressive shots to afford his opponent numerous chances.

O’Neill showed that this was a seriously perilous tactic in the first frame when he stepped in to make a break of 114 to take the lead.

The Rocket was no more circumspect in the second frame, taking on a low-percentage plant on a red which would ultimately cost him the frame and give O’Neill a 2-0 lead in a race to four.

Still the five-time champion would not relent in his ultra-attacking style, stroking in an ill-advised double, but then missing a difficult long blue to give his opponent yet another chance. However, O’Neill missed an easy long red and Ronnie stepped in, made a rapid-fire 90 and halved his deficit.

O’Sullivan took his average shot time to less than 14 seconds with that impressive break and certainly did not look like he was planning a long night in Crawley.

There was more of the same in the next as O’Neill missed an early opportunity afforded to him, allowing the Rocket to step back in and breeze round the table, making 102 to level the match.

The fifth frame started with the first real safety battle of the match, dragging both men’s average shot time up somewhat, it was O’Neill who broke the deadlock with an impressive long red before putting together a tricky and impressive break of 63.

Advertisement

Advertisement

O’Sullivan stepped back in with a good chance but missed a straight forward pink, although there was a hint of a kick, and the world number 105 returned to go within one frame of victory.

O’Neill was in again early in the sixth and looking assured, but on 33 he clipped a red with his cue when hampered on a shot, letting the Rocket back in.

He took more than a couple of visits to the table to get over the line, but he did just that and forced a decider.

A poor red from O’Neill gave O’Sullivan the first chance in the final frame, but he could only make 17 before missing a pink, however, he came back to the table with a two-point lead and another chance to wrap up victory. He made 81 and booked a spot in the second round.
